Hi Ron, thanks for that, yes that Tadashige ( or simular ) tsuba is in 
the=
 Akasaka book. It is much finer work indeed. This one of mine is like 
a cr=
oss between the Ito/Bush=FB ones around in books ( 3 different ones 
from m=
emory ) and the Akasaka though I thought mine with the running 
bones in th=
e Mimi and the seppa dai's shape may be a lter Akasaka, a 
students work or=
 something. I don't think it's bush=FB.

A good score on your behalf too ma=
te. Well done, can you post any pics 
of your tsuba ?.

Rich

Ron Hartmann =
wrote:

> Rich -
>
> Interesting to see this tsuba. My Akasaka of this desi=
gn signed 
> Tadashige (to my relief) passed shinsa in Chicago. Of course I=
 have it 
> here in front of me now to compare the work with your tsuba. Wh=
ile the 
> design is the same, the work on mine is more delicate (?)--more =

> piercing--and seems to "flow" more, if you know what I mean. The 
> hors=
e's hoofs on your tsuba are more "squared" and "bold" than the 
> more natu=
rally shaped hoofs on my tsuba. I just saw a similar tsuba 
> (picture) jus=
t the other day that showed these rather boldly made 
> hoofs and it was ca=
lled something other than Akasaka, but for the life 
> of me I don't recall=
 where I saw this. Thought it was in the new 
> Mosle' catalogue, but if so=
, I'm not finding it now. My tsuba came out 
> of a large collection of tsu=
ba sold in Santiago, Chile in 2003. That 
> collection also had another sim=
ilar "horse" tsuba that had these large 
> hoofs like your new tsuba, but I=
 didn't buy that one. Most of these 
> 730-plus tsuba were bought up by Mic=
hael Zomber, so perhaps your's 
> could be the one I saw. I'll check my rec=
ords.
>
> Ron
> STL
